section_title: HITS Hudson Valley — Venue Profile (Saugerties, NY)
section_overview: A big, efficient showgrounds built for volume and mileage. Multiple rings run simultaneously, so plan by ring cluster and keep one eye on in-gate texts. Warm-up rings are spacious but spike ahead of eq and derby classes—set your last oxer after a drag for the truest read. The jog strip is clearly posted near the hunter complex; come tidy, numbers visible, and step off with a forward trot. Vendor row sits along the main spine for quick-run fixes (gloves, studs, spur straps, last-minute braids). Stabling is organized by barns with good aisle width—fans secured, trunks flush, and ring bags staged for fast turnarounds. Footing is modern all-weather with frequent drags and water; expect consistent going from first trip to last. Golf carts help, but the quickest wins come from grouping your schooling by cluster and sending a runner between stabling and the in-gates.

section_spotlight.title: Quick Hits for HITS Hudson Valley
bullets: Warm-up windows: busiest 45 minutes pre-eq and jr/am hunters—book your last oxer right after a drag.
Jog strip: towel, hoof oil, alcohol spray at the ready; numbers front-and-center and a crisp forward trot.
Gate flow: multiple rings move on schedule—sync to in-gate texts and stage two trips ahead.
Footing feel: best once it’s packed—pop a vertical after a few early trips to gauge stride and rebound.
Stabling ops: wide aisles—keep fans secured, trunks flush, and a stocked ring bag by the door.
Routes: use the perimeter lanes to skip cart traffic on vendor row during peak times.
Derby/GP days: plan earlier schooling; warm-ups fill quickly and drag intervals tighten.
Weather watch: sun and breeze swing—stash spare gloves, rag, sunscreen, and a cool towel in your ring kit.
Parking/haul: unload cleanly and move—then group classes by ring cluster to cut back-and-forth.
Vendor row: braiding, studs, spur straps, hole punches—hit it between drags, not at last call.
Team roles: designate a ring runner and a tack runner; one floats at warm-up, one stages at stalls.
